title: Does empirical evidence include evidence acquired by a few people in extremely rare situations through their senses? - Quora

response.answer_text: Def:Empirical evidence (also empirical data, sense experience, empiricalknowledge, or the a posteriori) is a source of knowledge acquired by means of observation or experimentation So, I think not. A "few" People can be prone to hallucinations. So it might hold if the word "few" is replaced by "most".. (as per definition)If you stretch few to '1', we have prophets :-) None of their claims that : "God told them so" can be accepted as "empirical evidence" as per this definition.

Evidence is more or less valuable based on several factors, including  repeatability -- can other people repeat the observation and get the same result. When evidence is repeatable, it is readily accepted as fact.  Evidence becomes less reliable when it is not repeatable. Consider the recollections of a few eyewitnesses to a crime, or other one-time event. Eyewitness testimony is often unreliable because the witnesses were emotionally involved, stressed, rushed, only caught a glimpse of the event, witnessed an event in an unusual context, and have dynamic memories. This often causes one eyewitness account to conflict with another, even when the witnesses are doing their best to recall what they saw. Therefore eyewitness testimony is evidence, but it is not conclusive. See: Empirical evidenceand: Scientific evidenceand: Anecdotal evidenceand: Eyewitness memory

All evidence is subjective, to some degree. Personally, I am not aware of any evidence in any context, at any time, obtained under any circumstances, for any reason, that is NEVER, ever subject to interpretation via the senses. I am not at all sure what you mean by "rear situations." Please clarify.
No, the evidence needs to be tested, reproducible and well documented. Feelings are classed as Hearsay and thus not evidence.
